newsitem.title: USA: Florida Panthers stock falls after runup.
newsitem.headline: Florida Panthers stock falls after runup.

text.p: Florida Panthers Holdings Inc stock fell amid concerns that its recent run-up may have gone too far.

The stock had tripled since its November initial public offering, but it fell 2-1/2 to 29-1/2 in early trading after a Barron's article said some are shorting the stock because its current valuation is too high.

Raymond James & Associates analyst Budd Bugatch says the stock's meteoric rise was due to the Midas touch of owner Wayne Huizenga, with the "the Huizenga factor" adding an additional $500 million to the company's valuation.

The stock went public in November at $10 and flat-lined there until December 23, when an announcement that the hockey team's holding company would buy two hotels sent the stock soaring. It jumped to a $17 close on December 24 and peaked at $32.50 on January 24.

Wall Street is ignoring negative cash flow and focusing on the company's goal to become "a diversified leisure time based sports and entertainment company," stated in the December 23 announcement, the analyst said. He rated the stock accumulate in mid-January, when it was near $19.

Huizenga has built a reputation by acquiring diverse companies and weaving them into hugely successful industries such as Blockbuster video stores, now owned by Viacom Inc, and Republic Industries Inc.
"If their plan is to create an investment conglomerate, they have the capabilities to do so," Bugatch said.
The company's current valuation by Wall Street is at about $750 million dollars.
